column7: APA Group

APA Group is a leading Australian energy infrastructure business, owning, operating and managing a diverse $22 billion portfolio. We are proud of our role in delivering energy solutions to millions of customers in every State and Territory.

APA Group is a leading Australian energy infrastructure business, owning, operating and managing a diverse $22 billion portfolio. We are proud of our role in delivering energy solutions to millions of customers in every State and Territory.

column6: Information on employees and other workers
column7: APA is committed to being a responsible energy company where people are proud to work. We strive to create a healthy, safe, inclusive and diverse workplace.
APA manages the energy supply chain. APA realizes that this supply chain must be monitored for various risks so that it continues to impact stakeholders and the broader energy transition positively.

column6: Significant changes to the organization and its supply chain
column7: Our performance enabled the Board to declare a final distribution of 29.0 cents, taking the FY23 distribution to 55.0 cents per security, in line with guidance. It represents an increase of 3.8% in FY22 and has been delivered in parallel with our ongoing significant investment to build capability and capitalise on emerging growth opportunities.\t

The Precautionary Principle is implicitly and generally reflected in APAÃ¢ÂÂs approach to Risk Management via our Risk Appetite, Risk Management System (RMS) and the systematic application of risk assessment, risk management and risk communication through our HSEH Management System.

Financial Stability BoardÃ¢ÂÂs Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) Sustainability Accounting Standards Board (SASB) United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (UN SDGs) Workplace Gender Equality Agency (WGEA) Note: This list is not exhaustive.

FY23 associations: Australian Climate Leaders Coalition, Australian Hydrogen Council, Australian Pipeline and Gas Association, Bell Bay Advanced Manufacturing Zone, Business Council of Australia, CEDA, etc. & FY23 signatories: United Nations Global Compact, Energy Charter & Methane Guiding Principles

In FY23, APA Group reported a 2% increase in underlying EBITDA to $1,725 million, highlighted KMP changes, including a new CEO/MD and climate-related STI metrics, and made adjustments to the remuneration framework, increasing the STI maximum opportunity for KMP while maintaining a focus on long-term performance.

As a leading energy infrastructure business, APA is exposed to risks that can impact our energy delivery and financial success. APA uses a Risk Management Framework to manage material, operational, economic and compliance risks.

column6: Values, principles, standards, and norms of behavior
column13: Our Code brings our purpose and culture to life so we can make daily choices. Our courageous, accountable, agile, collaborative and impactful behaviours underpin it.\t

column6: Values, principles, standards, and norms of behavior
column8: Inclusion and Diversity Policy (including Equal Employment Opportunity)
column13: APA's commitment and strategy to building a diverse, equitable and truly inclusive workplace. APA hopes everyone belongs, feels valued, and respected to bring their best selves to work.

column6: Values, principles, standards, and norms of behavior
column8: Health, Safety, Environment and Heritage Policy
column13: We aspire not just to respect the past but to protect values for the future. We do this by protecting our people's health, safety, and well-being, as well as the environment, heritage, and communities in which we operate.

column6: Mechanisms for advice and concerns about ethics
column7: APA has some key policies governing ethics and integrity, including Code of Conduct, Inclusion and Diversity Policy (including Equal Employment Opportunity), Anti-Bribery and Corruption Policy, Whistleblower Policy, Respect@Work Procedure, and Health, Safety, Environment and Heritage Policy.

The Board has established five Committees to help it exercise its responsibilities and provide it with recommendations and advice. Each Committee has its charter that sets out its role, membership requirements, authority and responsibilities.

In FY23, APA has a board that manages the Audit and Finance Committee, Risk Management Committee, Safety and Sustainable Committee, People and Remuneration Committee, and Nomination Committee. They will delegate their duties to the CEO and Managing Director, then to the Executive Leadership Team.

column6: Consulting stakeholders on economic, environmental, and social topics
column13: In FY23, we appointed a reconciliation and First Nations manager to improve our First Nations' governance, performance, and disclosures. We established a crossfunctional RAP Working Group (RAPWG), chaired by an Executive Sponsor, to develop, implement and report on a Reflect RAP. With the support of our external advisor, Murawin Indigenous Voice Consultancy, we undertook an extensive internal consultation to co-design a quality RAP that meets Reconciliation AustraliaÃ¢ÂÂs standards.

column6: Composition of the highest governance body and its committees
column7: The Board determines its size and composition, subject to limits imposed by the Responsible EntityÃ¢ÂÂs constitution. The constitution provides for a minimum of three Directors and a maximum of 12.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: The Board has established five Committees to help it exercise its responsibilities and provide it with recommendations and advice. Each Committee has its charter that sets out its role, membership requirements, authority and responsibilities

column6: Nominating and selecting the highest governance body
column13: The Deed Poll gives Securityholders the right to nominate a person to fill any vacancy on the Board that arises on the retirement of a Director under the Ã¢ÂÂrotationÃ¢ÂÂ process or a Director appointed by the Board since the last Annual Meeting. APA publishes a Calendar of Events for the reporting period, which sets out the opening date and closing date for the receipt of nominations for Director.

Conflicts of interest are not uncommon, and we all need to be vigilant to manage them appropriately when they arise. We are committed to disclosing any relationships and removing ourselves from decision-making processes that may be perceived as a conflict of interest.

column6: Collective knowledge of highest governance body
column7: The Board considers that a diverse range of skills, experience and backgrounds is required on the Board to govern APA's business effectively. It determines and periodically reviews the mix of skills and knowledge it seeks to achieve in its membership, paying attention to the expertise and diversity of existing Directors.

column6: Evaluating the highest governance body's performance
column13: The Managing Director and the executive leadership team have service contracts setting out their responsibilities, conditions of service and termination entitlements. APA conducts appropriate reference and background checks before appointing any senior executive.

column6: Identifying and managing economic, environmental, and social impacts
column7: To continue delivering the most positive impact for APA and the highest value for our stakeholders, we must regularly re-evaluate the most important sustainability issues to our business and stakeholders. It will enable us to assess the economic, social, environmental and cultural impacts of our activities and business relationships and refine our main focus areas and associated initiatives.
